10 years after this

because in any moment of

77.98.text:

Now they're awesome
animals and this whole time

how to get close

Once I thought I'd mastered

Now I got my first

I was selected to be

107.47.text:
Now put simply, this
project brought together

121.82.text:
and prove that British

132.43.text:
while some of my colleagues,
they were getting to

He was actually my

so I thought I was stuck

I found out that you can

163.70.text: just as crazy as anywhere else.

And I found that the closer

169.70.text:
So everything down

Well in that little

204.67.text:
But it's not just the small

Now these are two rutting

209.11.text:
North American elk, and
every year in October

217.48.text:
And you might think that red

Well these two are

Now I was in Richmond Park

And just like I

I built up a map of all

246.55.text:
and there's just wildlife

250.38.text:
Now I'm particularly

252.39.text:
because I discovered

257.52.text:
Now, there's a few
reasons why peregrines

261.39.text:
Firstly, they're the

What really gets
me is that they are

278.21.text:

They start off brown and then

287.19.text:
Peregrines are a real
good news story in the UK,

289.62.text:
because when I was born in
1993, seeing a peregrine was

295.13.text:
A fleeting glimpse at an
estuary in Devon or something

298.50.text: was about as good as it got.

300.03.text:
Whereas now they're doing

305.87.text:
Now the reason they do well

308.31.text:
there's lots of food,

Cities are packed

So this is a female having a

326.56.text:

So these two chicks are

A really ominous looking

These aren't migrants, they're

346.71.text:
on this project and very

358.39.text:
I had one episode, that

364.40.text:

366.60.text:
to photograph this

And miles in the distance,

and said, "Can you please

388.42.text: Now how do you react to that?

390.66.text:
Back then, I wasn't very
good at dealing with these

404.34.text:
Just a teenage kid trying to

408.77.text:
As you can imagine, that didn't

411.58.text:
So I followed one particular
pair of peregrines

413.75.text:
that live in Bristol,
which is a city

417.32.text:
And I'm not normally
one to name wild animals

419.79.text:
but when something
like this happens,

426.46.text:
So this is the
chick on the right.

428.33.text:
The browner bird,
he's called Sam.

430.13.text:
And this is the
female on the left,

432.40.text:
and you can see the female is
about a third bigger than Sam.

435.50.text:
And that's not because she's
an adult and he's a chick,

437.87.text:
it's because she's a
female and he's a male.

439.97.text:
Female peregrines are about a
third bigger than the males.

443.01.text:
Now things were looking
really good for Sam,

444.24.text:
because his parents
were awesome hunters.

447.21.text:
They were catching pigeons
like there's no tomorrow.

450.95.text:
They'd bring 'em in,
he'd then wolf it down

452.82.text:
and screech at them to
go and get another one.

455.52.text:
He was also exercising
and stretching his wings,

458.66.text:
ready for his maiden
voyage, his first flight.

465.53.text:
Now this is where things went
a little bit pear-shaped.

468.67.text:
This is where the fairy
tale ends, I'm afraid.

471.50.text:
So Sam took his first flight,
he jumped off that building,

474.67.text:
and some gulls saw him and
they mobbed him down into

478.81.text:
the river which ran
below the nest building.

483.52.text:
If it had been in a normal
river in a wilder place,

485.78.text:
peregrines are actually
quite good swimmers.

487.59.text: They can kinda flap their wings

489.19.text: and get them over to the edge.

490.62.text:
But this was a city so
either bank was a six foot high

494.79.text:
vertical concrete bank, so
there was absolutely no way

497.16.text:
he was gonna get
out of the river.

498.83.text:
He'd also, being a wild
animal, chosen the one day

501.43.text:
in an entire month when
I wasn't standing on the

503.80.text:
main road, on the
bridge there to see him.

507.57.text:
Fortunately though, spending
all that time on the bridge

509.51.text:
had attracted quite
a lot of attention,

511.51.text:
particularly from two builders
who worked on a building site

514.15.text:
next door to the nest
building, and they saw Sam

516.75.text:
get mobbed down into the river
and they grabbed an umbrella

519.59.text: and they ran over to help.

521.59.text:
And they climbed down
on the ladder on the

522.99.text:
concrete river bank and
leaned off the ladder

525.36.text:
into the river and
tried to scoop Sam up

527.69.text: out the river with an umbrella.

530.33.text:
Unfortunately, Sam was a
little bit too far away.

533.77.text:
So one of the builders had
the idea of taking bricks.

537.24.text:
You know, it's a building
site, lots of bricks.

539.17.text:
And they threw them over
the top of Sam's head

542.44.text:
to create a wave, a
splash that would wash Sam

548.41.text:
Now when they told me
this story afterwards,

549.98.text:
I was like, "Guys, I don't know
if this is genius or crazy."

554.62.text:
"You threw bricks over
a protected species."

559.16.text: But it worked, they got Sam out.

565.26.text:
By the time they got Sam
out, it wasn't looking good,

568.73.text:
he was pretty much
dead, he wasn't moving,

570.77.text:
and the Bristol peregrine
expert Ed Drewitt

573.64.text:
was called to the scene,
and he decided the best plan

576.04.text:
of action would be to dry
Sam off, take him home,

580.98.text:
Both Ed and I thought Sam
wasn't gonna survive the night.

585.35.text:
But Sam is no
ordinary peregrine.

589.69.text:
In the morning, he
was fighting fit.

591.22.text: And we decided to release him.

592.73.text:
Now on that month I had on
that road had also attracted

595.49.text:
attention from a
couple of lawyers.

597.63.text:
They had an office
building really close to

599.16.text:
the nest building and they
said that we could release Sam

602.77.text:
So walking into an
office, lawyer's office,

606.21.text:
full of suited and booted
lawyers with a bird of prey

610.21.text:
in a towel in your hands does
get you some funny looks,

613.41.text: but it had to be done.

614.91.text:
We got Sam up onto the roof,
and you can see that blue band

616.85.text:
and the metal silver
band on his ankle.

619.49.text:
We put them on so that we
can track his movements.

621.42.text:
What scientists are finding
is that these urban peregrines

626.73.text:
The chicks disperse
all over the place.

630.36.text:
If a chick is born in a wilder
place like on the coast,

632.33.text:
they can come back
into the city.

635.70.text:
It's not genetic, it's
a behavioral thing,

638.24.text:
which is really
cool they can adapt.

639.74.text:
Three minutes later,
he took flight.

642.01.text:
And bearing in mind how
his first flight had gone,

644.18.text: our hearts were in our mouths.

647.35.text:
But he made it back to the
nest building, woo hoo.

649.01.text:
And just two days after this
near drowning experience,

651.42.text:
I saw him flying high
alongside here the adult female

656.02.text: who again has got a pigeon.

657.79.text:
Now this is how the adults
teach the youngsters to hunt.

660.16.text:
They'll kill or disable a pigeon
and then let the youngster

662.66.text:
come up from underneath,
take it off of him

664.16.text:
so they can practice
flying with weight.

667.77.text:
Only problem was,
Sam was just rubbish

672.10.text:
It's like, come on,
dude, up your game.

675.31.text:
Now just after I took this
picture, Sam dropped the pigeon,

681.61.text:
Now the problem with
dropping a pigeon in a city

685.45.text:
is that it tends to
land on someone's head.

689.05.text:
And of all the places he could
have dropped that pigeon,

691.59.text:
he dropped it in
between two tables

695.03.text:
in the outside restaurant
of the Marriott Hotel.

699.16.text:
So you can imagine the look
on these people's faces

702.23.text:
when they're halfway
through their main course,

703.70.text:
and this blood covered beheaded
pigeon lands next to them.

708.04.text:
This was a really cool
wildlife experience,

710.44.text:
but the thing that
I love most about it

711.88.text:
was how it brought
together so many people

716.48.text:
We had the builders, the
suited and booted lawyers,

718.72.text:
and all these passers by that
would walk on this main road

720.99.text:
that showed such a keen
interest in these peregrines.

724.79.text:
Perhaps most promising was that
parents who they themselves

728.29.text:
admitted to having little
interest in nature

730.46.text:
were bringing their
kids down to watch Sam

732.96.text: and his mom and dad in action,

735.13.text:
and I think that's the
power of urban wildlife.

737.74.text:
Most of us will never
see a polar bear,

741.34.text:
Modern day society is so
disconnected from nature.

743.91.text:
Urban wildlife provides a
bit of a bridge to that gap,

747.85.text:
so please get out and see
what wildlife you can find

750.78.text: if you live in a city.
